awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Integrating Research in Sustainable Energy and the Environment across Disciplines  (IR-SEED)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK) seeks to provide impactful summer research opportunities and experiences to underrepresented students in the emerging fields of sustainable energy and environment. This will enable them to understand their own levels of aptitude and interest in a career in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and give them the tools to prepare for the next stage in education and career development. The intellectual merit of this REU Site lies in constructing a new and critically needed pipeline for the next generation of sustainable energy researchers, equipped to address the broad theme of sustainable energy research and social and environmental issues, which is a theme of local significance and global implications. The research, educational, and career mentorship provided by the program is envisioned to stimulate the students to look at their academic work in a new light and to provide a spark for possible careers in academic research or industrial innovation. Participating students will tackle various research topics by working collaboratively with other participants, interact with faculty mentors and Ph.D. students from different engineering departments, and develop a holistic perspective of sustainable energy and environment research. The site is designed to guide students to work both independently and collaboratively, with each team consisting of two undergraduate students. Each student will be required to write a conference paper style report of their research for publication and deliver an oral and poster presentation of their summer research projects in the final competition at the end of 10-week program. The REU site fits within an initiative in the College of Engineering at TAMUK to involve undergraduate students in research and boost the participation of US citizens (especially Hispanic and female students) in graduate research. The REU site builds on a vision of grooming aspiring researchers from underrepresented groups to embrace the challenge of energy research and developing future leaders who proactively contribute to the nation's energy self-reliance agenda.

This REU Site is designed to develop and implement a model environment for multidisciplinary collaborative efforts where research and education are tightly integrated around the different facets of sustainable energy and environment research. Ten students from various engineering and science departments will be recruited through a nationwide search with special emphasis on Hispanic and female students. It features a 10-week interdisciplinary team approach to mentoring students on different research projects. The proposed sustainable energy research consists of three major research areas: 1) Energy Harvesting, 2) Energy Utilization, and 3) Energy Policy, Environmental and Social Impacts. The specific objectives are: 1) providing research opportunities in the different aspects of energy research to undergraduate students, especially Hispanic and women; 2) increasing the number of underrepresented students who participate in graduate education; and 3) building collaborative links among faculty and students from different engineering departments at TAMUK. Through participation in cutting-edge research with faculty mentors working at the forefront of their respective disciplines, students will engage in complex scientific studies on sustainable energy and environment research topics. The program is structured to teach students how to formulate research questions and develop/modify research plans with the guidance of their research mentors. In addition to the hands-on collaborative research experience, technical and social activities will be incorporated into the program to provide students with a solid foundation in analytical, writing, and presentation skills, helping to enhance the interaction between REU students and faculty mentors. The students will also gain experience with reporting and discussing their research results in multiple settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site: Integrating Research in Sustainable Energy and the Environment across Disciplines (IR-SEED) hosted at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK) and supported by the National Science Foundation's Division of Engineering Education and Centers was designed to develop and implement a model environment for multidisciplinary collaborative efforts where research and education were tightly integrated around the different facets of energy research. With the support of the REU site itself and two supplement grants, the IR-SEED REU site supported 30 REU participants, one community college teacher, and one middle school teacher between 2018 and 2023. The REU site addressed the broader theme of sustainable energy research and social and environmental issues. In three years (2019, 2021, and 2022), the REU site received 220 completed applications from over 80 different universities in more than 25 states across the nation and supported 30 REU participants, including 10 Hispanic, 2 African American, and 15 female students. The 30 REU participants, from 19 different universities in 9 different states, completed 15 different research projects in 10-week summer research program in three major areas: 1) Renewable Energy (7 projects), 2) Conventional Clean Energy (3 projects), 3) Energy Policy, Environmental & Social Impacts (5 projects). All 15 projects were either part of ongoing funded research projects or related to graduate students’ ongoing thesis or dissertation research projects, including wind/solar energy, water/air pollution prevention, smart grid and cybersecurity, energy management and building energy efficiency. Seven tenure-track and two tenured faculty mentors (1 female and 2 Hispanic faculty) and 9 graduate assistants (2 PhD students and 6 second-year M.S. students) from all 5 different departments in the College of Engineering at TAMUK served as mentors in this REU site.

The REU participants published four conference papers, and eight conference abstracts/posters as co-authors based on their research results. The PIs, faculty advisers, and graduate students published three journal papers and four conference papers related to the REU projects.

Pre- and post-surveys and follow-up phone interviews were conducted to collect REU participants’ feedback. More than 91% of REU participants rated their overall experience as excellent or very good. Based on the survey and phone interview results, this REU site had a very positive impact on REU participants. It was able to provide an environment that allowed students to gain knowledge and skills, encouraged their continuation in research, and provided important information needed for their decisions about graduate school and careers. Faculty and graduate student mentors provided good support and guidance for REU participants. REU participants themselves realized significant improvements in different aspects, including formulating a research question, planning a research project, conducting research, making technical presentations, etc.

In the three cohorts of REU students, two REU participants worked on different tasks under the same research project as small groups instead of individual research projects, which showed the advantages of helping engage REU participants during and after the REU program. Meanwhile, group projects make it easier to get more results for journal/conference publications compared with individual projects, so that faculty and REU participants would work together to publish their results.

The IR-SEED REU site received full support from different offices at TAMUK, including the Vice President for Research, Dean of the College of Engineering, Associate Vice President for Student Success, Associate Vice President for Student Access, Housing Department, and Recreation Center. With all the support, the REU site was able to provide different services and training to the REU participants, including 1) a reserved classroom with computers and printers/scanners, 2) visiting student ID cards to access most TAMUK facilities including library, campus shuttle, etc. 3) apply keys of the reserved classroom and necessary laboratories, 4) creating university student account for accessing internet and computers, 5) offer different professional development seminars, 6) offer different research seminars, 7) offer access to recreation center, and 8) provide the best dorm at TAMUK.  Local stakeholders offered field trip opportunities, including Corpus Christi Army Depot, Naval Air Station Kingsville, and FAA Lone Star UAS Center.
